text1: A vegan society would be the most effective at combating climate change.
text2: Cultivated meat is a more environmentally sustainable method of creating conventional food.

text1: Vegan diets are associated with reduced greenhouse gas emissions and a much lower carbon footprint (p. 1).
text2: The research on veganism's impact on greenhouse gases is inconsistent.

text1: Vegan diets are associated with reduced greenhouse gas emissions and a much lower carbon footprint (p. 1).
text2: When considered per calorie, vegetarian diets may actually produce more greenhouse gas emissions than those of omnivores.

text1: Vegan diets are associated with reduced greenhouse gas emissions and a much lower carbon footprint (p. 1).
text2: Vegan diets are often reliant on highly processed meat and dairy alternatives, meaning that most are no more environmentally beneficial (in terms of their carbon footprint) than an ovo-lacto-vegetarian diet (pp. 6-7).

text1: Animal agriculture is a major contributor to global warming. A global move to a vegan diet could reduce food-related greenhouse gas emissions (which make up 37% of human-activity emissions) by two-thirds by 2050 (p. 4146).
text2: A vegan society would be more dependent on imported foods, making transport emissions even worse.

text1: Methane from cows and other livestock constitutes 44% of human-produced methane in the atmosphere.
text2: Converting livestock methane into biogas could reduce the methane emissions from animal agriculture.

text1: Most food-related greenhouse gas emissions occur during production, with final transport to retail only contributing 4% of the total emissions (p. 3508).
text2: Many vegan foods travel more miles than meat, contributing to a higher overall carbon footprint.

text1: CO₂ emissions from increased transport would still likely pale in comparison to those produced in animal agriculture.
text2: A vegan society would be more dependent on imported foods, making transport emissions even worse.

text1: Plants grown for food absorb CO₂.
text2: The net absorption of CO₂ by plants is low enough that it does not contribute much to greenhouse gas reduction.

text1: Kelp and other seaweeds are high protein food stuffs that absorb CO₂ more effectively than trees.
text2: Kelp and seaweed, which help absorb greenhouse gases in the ocean, are often farmed using unsustainable methods such as dredging.

text1: Global adherence to a vegan diet would contribute to carbon sequestration.
text2: Developing more properly-managed grazing spaces for cattle by regenerating grasslands may help capture more carbon than the animals produce.

text1: Carbon sinks will eventually reach their limit (p. 2708), and grasslands supporting grass-fed cattle only store 20-60% of the greenhouse gases produced by the grazing cattle.
text2: Developing more properly-managed grazing spaces for cattle by regenerating grasslands may help capture more carbon than the animals produce.

text1: The problem of climate change is urgent. Governments must cut emissions in all areas as quickly as possible to have a realistic chance of limiting it. Therefore, even if green energy is adopted, humans should still go vegan.
text2: As industries increasingly transition to sustainable fuel sources, the reduction of global emissions may be accomplished by means other than the elimination of the meat industry.

text1: Research suggests that - without considerable changes to its production methods and infrastructure - cultivated beef would not have a significantly reduced carbon footprint when compared to beef from cattle (p. 8)
text2: Cultivated meat is a more environmentally sustainable method of creating conventional food.

text1: A vegan society would create the least pollution.

text1: A vegan society would create the least pollution.
text2: Vegan foods and products often contain - or are packaged in - non-biodegradable materials.

text1: Pollution caused by grazing damages river systems.
text2: Rotational grazing can help reduce damage to river systems without abandoning animal agriculture entirely (p. 2118).

text1: Many waterways are polluted with farm animal faeces, causing the water to contain levels of nitrogen and phosphorus that are unsafe for human consumption (p. vii).
text2: Regenerative animal agriculture can benefit waterways and oceans.

text1: Human faeces is vegan and could be a replacement for animal manure.
text2: Manure is sustainable, while fertilizer mining is not.

text1: Technological advances, such as fertilizer rationing software, can reduce fertilizer use.
text2: If all societies became vegan, the use of chemical fertilizers would dramatically increase due to the loss of animal fertilizer. This switch is not a sustainable or eco-friendly option.

text1: Chemical fertilizers are safer for human health than manure.

text1: Many plastic-free stores are vegan or vegetarian.

text1: People may become environmentally complacent even if they are not vegan.

text2: Vegetation-rich areas that are unsuitable for crop agriculture can be used for grazing, reducing the need for other, environmentally damaging animal feed sources.

text1: Animal flocks could still be held for their environmental benefits without harming or exploiting them.
text2: Livestock farming can benefit the environment.

text1: Animal flocks could still be held for their environmental benefits without harming or exploiting them.

text1: Pasture animals can damage biodiversity.

text1: Pasture animals can damage biodiversity.
text2: In many instances, livestock grazing is crucial for biodiversity.

text1: Livestock produce 14.5% of all CO₂ equivalent greenhouse gases (p. xii), while all transportation produces 14% of all CO₂ equivalent greenhouse gases. Becoming vegan would have an environmental effect similar to stopping all travel.
text2: Travel has a significant negative impact on the environment.

text1: Currently, there are few, if any, alternatives to extremely polluting forms of long-distance travel.
text2: Travel has a significant negative impact on the environment.

text1: It is possible to immediately decide to be vegan. Other environmental decisions, such as changing to renewable energy, are not always available in the short term.
text2: People's eating habits are not the most important issue that should be addressed to save the environment.

text1: Given the severity of the climate emergency, people ought to do as much as possible to limit their carbon footprint. There is, therefore, nothing contradictory in both becoming vegan and fighting against other sources of climate change.
text2: People's eating habits are not the most important issue that should be addressed to save the environment.

text1: Veganism reduces both human and animal suffering.
text2: Humans have the right to treat animals in such a way as meets their needs. As such, they have few obligations to minimize the suffering of animals.

text1: Veganism reduces both human and animal suffering.
text2: Many vegan practices and portrayals of veganism are racist. These would become more harmful and widespread if everyone were vegan.

text1: Veganism reduces both human and animal suffering.

text1: The meat industry significantly harms its workers and nearby communities.

text1: The meat industry significantly harms its workers and nearby communities.
text2: The meat industry employs half a million people in the US and has brought employment to previously depressed areas (p. 1).

text1: Slaughterhouse employees report that their work severely affects their emotional and mental health, which also often impacts their families and communities.
text2: There are a number of other professions that are seen also as mentally stressful and traumatic, yet society does not consider these necessary to eradicate.

text1: Safety standards in the meat industry are poor.
text2: Worker safety standards differ between countries and can be improved regardless of whether all humans are vegan.

text1: If everyone were vegan, global agricultural land usage would decrease by 75%. This would result in far fewer farmers, likely improving working conditions.
text2: Many crops are picked by migrant farmers that face sexual, verbal, and physical abuse, as well as health problems and low pay (p. 6).

text1: Ethical issues with vegan production chains result from broader exploitative production systems, not veganism itself.
text2: Many crops are picked by migrant farmers that face sexual, verbal, and physical abuse, as well as health problems and low pay (p. 6).

text1: Animals raised for human use are often treated cruelly.
text2: It is not in the meat industry's interest to treat animals cruelly, as mistreating cattle results in poorer quality meat (p. 6).

text1: Animals raised for human use are often treated cruelly.
text2: While it may seem cruel, academic and laboratory research often requires animal testing and experimentation in order to create products that save the lives of humans and animals alike.

text1: Animals raised for human use are often treated cruelly.
text2: There are more ethical routes to obtain animal products that emphasize animal welfare and dignity.

text1: In the dairy industry, some calves are removed from their mothers at birth or killed if it is too expensive to rear them.
text2: Long-term studies found no evidence that calves suffer behaviourally or developmentally when separated from their mothers (p. 5550).

text1: Not all forms of cruelty result in inferior quality meat.
text2: Meat producers usually want animals to die quickly to prevent pain-associated chemicals from forming, which may spoil the meat (p. 1).

text1: Crueler methods of livestock management allow farms to increase the quantity they produce at a lower cost. Even if some consumers resent lower quality, cruel farms will likely be more profitable.
text2: It is not in the meat industry's interest to treat animals cruelly, as mistreating cattle results in poorer quality meat (p. 6).

text1: Many slaughterhouses have been caught flouting animal cruelty laws, resulting in animals experiencing immense suffering before their deaths.
text2: It is not in the meat industry's interest to treat animals cruelly, as mistreating cattle results in poorer quality meat (p. 6).

text2: While it may seem cruel, academic and laboratory research often requires animal testing and experimentation in order to create products that save the lives of humans and animals alike.

text2: Purchasing from small-scale producers of animal products is more ethical than purchasing from industrial farms.

text2: Purchasing from small-scale producers of animal products is more ethical than purchasing from industrial farms.

text1: Humane farming still necessitates slaughter or mutilation. As such, it does not meaningfully reduce the suffering inflicted upon animals.

text1: Humane farming still necessitates slaughter or mutilation. As such, it does not meaningfully reduce the suffering inflicted upon animals.
text2: Organic farming places a strong emphasis on animal welfare and requires that animals are kept healthy and in humane conditions.

text1: Halal and kosher slaughter methods may actually be crueler than secular farming methods, as they do not stun the animals before killing them, causing more suffering.
text2: The slaughter of animals using kosher or halal rules makes the process as quick and painless as possible (p. 31).

text1: Ethical farming practices are rarely used, meaning most people do not have access to - or cannot afford - ethically produced meat.

text1: Ethical farming practices are rarely used, meaning most people do not have access to - or cannot afford - ethically produced meat.
text2: Many countries have begun mandating that animals be stunned before slaughter, making the process significantly less painful for the animal.

text1: A vegan society would cause singificantly less harm to wildlife.
text2: If all humans go vegan, entire ecosystems could be disrupted by the overpopulation of livestock if they were released into the wild.

text1: In a vegan world, fewer species would be at risk of extinction.
text2: Properly managed animal farming can benefit biodiversity.

text1: Industrial agriculture can dangerously decrease animal populations.
text2: Sustainable livestock farming is not contributing to significant decreases in animal populations. Decreasing animal populations is a problem specific to industrial livestock farming.

text2: If lost herds are not replaced with ruminant animals, deserts will be created, causing far more environmental damage than animal greenhouse gases.

text2: If lost herds are not replaced with ruminant animals, deserts will be created, causing far more environmental damage than animal greenhouse gases.

text1: Industrial farming is a major cause of the loss of biodiversity.
text2: Properly managed animal farming can benefit biodiversity.

text1: Animal agriculture severely harms wildlife as farmers tend to kill wildlife in order to protect their livestock (p. 1).
text2: Wild pigs are destructive, costing the US an estimated $2.5 billion yearly in damages and control costs. It is therefore appropriate for farmers to kill these animals.

text1: Many invasive species have been introduced to new territories on vegan crops.
text2: Human-introduced species have historically devastated local wildlife populations across the world.

text1: Feral animals are proof that domesticated animals - including livestock - can successfully return to the wild.
text2: Not only would releasing livestock into the wild be unethical in terms of its impact on wildlife, but it would be unethical in terms of the harms it would inflict on livestock, who have not been bred to survive in the wild.

text1: Effective vegan methods to control animal populations exist.
text2: If all humans go vegan, entire ecosystems could be disrupted by the overpopulation of livestock if they were released into the wild.

text1: Effective vegan methods to control animal populations exist.
text2: Hunting can be a more effective method to control overpopulation and invasive animal species, and can rebalance ecosystems..

text1: Neutering can reduce population sizes without killing any animals.
text2: The castration of farm animals is routinely performed surgically and without anaesthesia. Any en-masse neutering for population control would likely be performed in the same way, causing significant suffering.

text1: Anaesthesia has been used when neutering wild cats. This suggests it could be used when neutering farm animals, even if it is not currently.
text2: The castration of farm animals is routinely performed surgically and without anaesthesia. Any en-masse neutering for population control would likely be performed in the same way, causing significant suffering.

text1: Inflicting some amount of pain and distress on animals is better than killing them.
text2: The castration of farm animals is routinely performed surgically and without anaesthesia. Any en-masse neutering for population control would likely be performed in the same way, causing significant suffering.

text2: Hunting can be a more effective method to control overpopulation and invasive animal species, and can rebalance ecosystems..

text1: Natural selection will correct for species' overpopulation eventually.

text2: If all humans go vegan, entire ecosystems could be disrupted by the overpopulation of livestock if they were released into the wild.

text1: Most of the animals killed by humans for food - such as cows, pigs, and chickens - do not usually kill humans or each other.
text2: Humans are just another type of animal. Therefore, we are only as morally obliged not to kill or dominate other species as they are morally obliged not to kill or dominate each other.

text1: Most of the animals killed by humans for food - such as cows, pigs, and chickens - do not usually kill humans or each other.
text2: Most predators are not eaten by their prey. The fact that gazelles do not eat lions is not a reason to stop lions from eating gazelles.

text1: The fact that an action is natural does not imply that it is moral.
text2: It is natural for humans to subordinate animals for their needs.

text1: It is rare for humans to desire to kill animals, and their physiology suggests they are not designed to do so.
text2: It is natural for humans to subordinate animals for their needs.

text1: It is rare for humans to desire to kill animals, and their physiology suggests they are not designed to do so.
text2: There is evidence that humans have innate hunting traits and possess a natural hunting instinct.

text1: Human bodies are largely not able to kill animals on their own, implying it is not natural to do so. Humans often need tools to kill animals, unlike other predators.
text2: Many non-human animals use tools to kill their prey.

text1: Infants do not possess the rational faculties of adults, yet are considered to have rights.
text2: Since animals do not possess free will to the same extent as humans, they cannot have the same rights (p. 538).

text1: A lack of free will may mean that animals do not have positive rights, but they could still have negative rights, for which free will is not necessary.
text2: Since animals do not possess free will to the same extent as humans, they cannot have the same rights (p. 538).

text1: From a biological and psychological perspective, the distinction between humans and animals is small.
text2: The fact that humans have greater rational faculties than animals makes them entitled to do what they wish with animals.

text1: From a biological and psychological perspective, the distinction between humans and animals is small.
text2: To be a moral actor, one must be capable of making moral decisions. Animals do not have this ability.

text1: From a biological and psychological perspective, the distinction between humans and animals is small.
text2: Complex cognitive differences in how humans think and experience emotions mean that it is natural for us to perceive ourselves as superior to other animals.

text1: Just like humans, animals desire to live.
text2: An animal's desire to live does not imply its right to live. Under the concept of survival of the fittest, everything wants to survive, but only the fittest will.

text1: A number of animals have passed the mirror test, proving that they can recognise themselves as individuals.
text2: The mirror test is a very unreliable test of self-awareness.

text1: Even if morals only apply to human actions, they still constrain what humans are morally allowed to do to animals.
text2: To be a moral actor, one must be capable of making moral decisions. Animals do not have this ability.

text1: It is immoral to do harm to a person who is asleep or in a temporary coma as they are still moral agents. The same applies to animals.
text2: To be a moral actor, one must be capable of making moral decisions. Animals do not have this ability.

text1: Many mammals can experience similar mental conditions to humans, including depression, Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder, and anxiety disorders.
text2: Complex cognitive differences in how humans think and experience emotions mean that it is natural for us to perceive ourselves as superior to other animals.

text1: Animals should be considered to have innate rights, which are violated by non-vegan practices. Therefore, eating animals relies on speciesist conceptions of animals.
text2: Humans have the right to treat animals in such a way as meets their needs. As such, they have few obligations to minimize the suffering of animals.

text1: Animals should be considered to have innate rights, which are violated by non-vegan practices. Therefore, eating animals relies on speciesist conceptions of animals.
text2: Plants have many of the qualities generally used to justify granting rights to humans and animals. By this logic, they too should have individual rights.

text2: That plants react to damage is evidence that these organisms do not want to die.

text2: Plants have many of the qualities generally used to justify granting rights to humans and animals. By this logic, they too should have individual rights.

text2: Plants have many of the qualities generally used to justify granting rights to humans and animals. By this logic, they too should have individual rights.

text1: Plants lack the nervous system and pain receptors necessary to experience pain, and its accompanying emotions, in the way that sentient beings do (p. 883).

text1: The fact that animals can suffer makes them worthy of moral concern and implies that humans ought to not consume them.
text2: Humans have the right to treat animals in such a way as meets their needs. As such, they have few obligations to minimize the suffering of animals.

text1: The fact that animals can suffer makes them worthy of moral concern and implies that humans ought to not consume them.
text2: A being’s ability to suffer does not entitle them to specific protections or rights.

text1: The experience of pain and pleasure is the most important moral consideration there is. Since animals can experience them, it is wrong to inflict unnecessary suffering on them.
text2: A being’s ability to suffer does not entitle them to specific protections or rights.

text1: The lack of representation of people of color is a general problem of these countries. It is not caused by, but rather reflected in, veganism.
text2: Veganism is typically depicted using white, affluent individuals, despite its non-white roots.

text1: Veganism is primarily a first-world trend and is most popular in Western countries and cities.
text2: Veganism is typically depicted using white, affluent individuals, despite its non-white roots.

text1: Comparisons between human and animal suffering effectively challenge the mismatch between our moral considerations of humans and animals.
text2: Advertisements for veganism have made problematic comparisons between the suffering of animals and the suffering experienced by minority communities.

text1: In a world where everyone is vegan, there would be no need for advertisements for veganism.
text2: Advertisements for veganism have made problematic comparisons between the suffering of animals and the suffering experienced by minority communities.

text2: Many vegan practices and portrayals of veganism are racist. These would become more harmful and widespread if everyone were vegan.

text1: Bees would pollinate plants regardless of whether they are industrially grown by farmers or exist in the wild. Therefore, the role of pollination in the agriculture industry does not constitute exploitation.

text1: Since a number of prominent vegan organizations have been very critical of palm oil, many vegans avoid using it.
text2: Farmers have historically taken land away from wildlife to farm crops, threatening some species. This is especially true of palm oil cultivation.

text1: Although top allergens are also the top vegan protein sources (soy and wheat), most vegan companies offer products made from peas and almonds.

text1: People can successfully live with IBS while following a vegan diet.

text1: People with hemochromatosis can benefit greatly from a vegan diet due to plants' less absorbable nonheme iron (p. 66).
text2: Plant sources of iron only contain nonheme forms of iron, while meat sources contain both heme and nonheme. Having both sources makes iron more available for absorption and use in the body.

text1: The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition has argued that vegans generally have adequate iron intake and do not experience anemia at a higher rate than others (p. 1629S).
text2: Some medications and medical conditions can create predispositions for anaemia, which can cause blindness (p. 1). As vegan diets can be low in iron, veganism can be dangerous for people with these conditions.

text1: Many older people experience heart problems, which are often exacerbated by eating large amounts of red or processed meat.
text2: Many older people already struggle with health complications. Malnutrition, which is more commonly seen in vegan diets, could make these health conditions worse.

text1: A study found no link between orthorexia nervosa and veganism or vegetarianism, instead citing ethical reasons as the motivation behind these diets (p. 1).
text2: Attempting to adhere to a strict vegan diet can lead to orthorexia, an obsession with eating a "pure" diet.

text1: If everyone were vegan, veganism would no longer be seen as restrictive. This would diminish the attractiveness of veganism to people with restrictive eating disorders.
text2: Veganism can be adopted as a way to legitimise continued restrictive eating behaviour (pp. 5-6).

text1: The belief that veganism exacerbates eating disorders is a stereotype which is often perpetuated by disorder treatment centers.
text2: The restrictive nature of a vegan diet may exacerbate eating disorders or trigger those who suffer from them.

text1: There is no evidence of a direct causal link between veganism and eating disorders.
text2: The restrictive nature of a vegan diet may exacerbate eating disorders or trigger those who suffer from them.

text1: Many processed vegan foods are fortified with nutrients typically found in animal products.

text1: Many processed vegan foods are fortified with nutrients typically found in animal products.

text1: Many processed vegan foods are fortified with nutrients typically found in animal products.

text1: There are very few people for whom some version of a vegan diet is not advisable.
text2: Some medical conditions and medication that affect nutrition can prevent a person from going vegan.

text1: Children of vegetarian mothers do not have a higher incidence of brain development issues than the children of omnivores (p. 1).
text2: Unless carefully balanced, a vegan diet can impair brain development in children.

text1: Mothers can breastfeed their children for years, and breast milk from vegan mothers has comparable nutritional value to that of non-vegans.
text2: Deficiencies common in vegan diets increase the risk of growth and developmental problems in children and babies.

text2: Some vegans do not believe that breastfeeding is vegan. Avoiding breastfeeding is nutritionally sub-optimal, as breastmilk is a complete nutrient source.

text1: Children are often pressured into eating meat by their parents, cultural conditioning, and advertisements (p. 6).
text2: Since a strict vegan diet may not meet the nutritional requirements of children and adolescents (p. 6), it should not be forced on children until they are old enough to choose it for themselves.

text1: Children are often pressured into eating meat by their parents, cultural conditioning, and advertisements (p. 6).
text2: Since babies and young children cannot decide what they eat, all food (including plant-based food) is essentially forced upon them.

text1: Parents should have the right to raise a child in accordance with their own values. When they are old enough, children can make their own decisions.
text2: Since a strict vegan diet may not meet the nutritional requirements of children and adolescents (p. 6), it should not be forced on children until they are old enough to choose it for themselves.

text1: Parents should have the right to raise a child in accordance with their own values. When they are old enough, children can make their own decisions.
text2: If a parent thinks that stealing is acceptable, that does not mean they should be allowed to raise their child to be a thief.

text1: Disabled vegan advocates have argued that special accommodations can be made for disabled people where necessary.
text2: Many people with common disabilities may find veganism more challenging due to the time, energy, and fine motor skills required to prepare many vegan foods.

text1: Vegan diets can be adaptable and suitable for many kinds of complex or specific dietary needs. For example, there is mounting evidence that a plant-based diet can benefit athletes despite their complex nutritional needs.
text2: A vegan diet is not well-suited for vulnerable individuals or people with lifestyles requiring specialised nutrition, who may be unable to remove animal products from their diet.

text1: Vegan diets can be adaptable and suitable for many kinds of complex or specific dietary needs. For example, there is mounting evidence that a plant-based diet can benefit athletes despite their complex nutritional needs.
text2: Iron and zinc are two of the most common nutrient deficiencies in athletes' diets, and are nutrients which are largely unavailable in vegan diets.

text1: It is currently virtually impossible for vegans to entirely avoid animal products. As such, people should be considered vegan if they do as much as possible to remove animal products from their lives, even if they have to use them on occasion.
text2: A vegan diet is not well-suited for vulnerable individuals or people with lifestyles requiring specialised nutrition, who may be unable to remove animal products from their diet.

text1: A study detailing individuals with a low normal or deficient B12 range showed that there is no significant difference the between those who eat meat and those who do not (pp. 514-515).
text2: Those following a vegan diet are at an increased risk of vitamin B12 deficiency.

text2: Those following a vegan diet are at an increased risk of vitamin B12 deficiency.

text1: Many vegan foods are fortified with bacteria-derived vitamin B12. B12 in fortified foods has greater bioavailability than that found in animal products.
text2: Those following a vegan diet are at an increased risk of vitamin B12 deficiency.

text1: Omega-3 and DHA are both readily available from a number of vegan food products and supplements.

text2: Vegans are more deficient than meat-eaters in the omega-3 fatty acids EPA and DHA (p. 333).

text2: Supplements do not replace the need for a varied diet.

text2: The nutrients in supplements may not be absorbed during digestion as effectively as those in whole foods, making them less optimal to fill the gaps left by animal products.

text1: Research suggests that no significant vitamin or mineral deficiencies affect the vegan population compared to non-vegans (p. 2). This is largely because most core vitamins can be easily obtained on a vegan diet.
text2: It is often necessary for a vegan diet to include food supplements, as it lacks specific essential nutrients contained in a healthy diet.

text1: Research suggests that no significant vitamin or mineral deficiencies affect the vegan population compared to non-vegans (p. 2). This is largely because most core vitamins can be easily obtained on a vegan diet.

text2: Some vegan foods contain anti-nutrients. These can prevent people from absorbing nutrients they would typically get from meat.

text1: Some vegan foods, like quinoa, can provide vegans with a complete protein source.

text1: Concerns about protein consumption in developed countries are exaggerated. Most vegans already get plenty of protein in their diets.
text2: Protein consumption among older people is too low in some countries (p. 1).

text1: While many Americans consume sufficient amounts of protein, the processed meat they consume to obtain it is often high in sugar and fat. Getting protein primarily from plant sources may help tackle this issue.
text2: Many animal products provide a complete protein source, whereas most vegan foods do not. As a result, obtaining enough high quality, bioavailable protein through a vegan diet can be challenging.

text1: Many expert organizations agree that a vegan diet can be as healthy as an omnivorous one (p. 1).
text2: The WHO has warned that meat substitutes can lead to negative health impacts, despite many people considering them to be part of a healthy vegan diet.

text1: The Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics (AND) has supported a well-planned vegan diet as nutritionally healthy and adequate since 2009 (p. 1266).
text2: While it may back veganism as a healthy option, the AND's lack of diversity among its members and within its research suggests it may not support marginalised communities to follow such a lifestyle.

text1: Veganism can help prevent the emergence and spread of diseases.

text1: Veganism can help prevent the emergence and spread of diseases.

text1: The raising and selling of livestock as meat spreads food-borne and zoonotic diseases (such as E. coli, toxoplasmosis, and swine flu). A vegan society reduces the potential that pathogens will transfer between animals and humans.

text1: Some of the worst disease outbreaks in human history have been linked to poor conditions in meat markets and factory farms. Universal veganism would reduce the likelihood of these outbreaks.

text1: Animal diseases are more likely to pass to humans than diseases in plant crops due to genetic and biochemical similarities.
text2: Plant-based agriculture can also spread diseases.

text1: A vegan diet may help reduce the risk of certain lifestyle diseases.

text2: Some people gain weight on a vegan diet.

text1: A vegan diet can help prevent heart disease, which is the leading cause of human death worldwide.
text2: Vegans can still eat some of the unhealthy aspects of an omnivore's diet (such as saturated fat, sugar, and salt). Healthy diets need to reduce all foods that increase the risk of heart disease, not just animal-based ones.

text2: Healthy non-vegan diets can be low in cholesterol.

text1: Since it lowers the level dietary cholesterol, a vegan diet significantly reduces the risk of ischemic heart disease compared to an omnivorous diet (p. 3640).

text2: Only consuming organic crops reduces exposure to pesticides.

text1: Vegan foods can be more readily and cheaply preserved for longer.

text2: World hunger is not currently caused by a lack of food but by geopolitical inequalities and conflicts (p. 14).
